titleStmt.title: Morphological aspects of making the world's strongest fiber

analytic.title: Morphological aspects of making the world's strongest fiber

div.head: Names and affiliations of applicants (* indicates experimentalists):
Jinyu Li (DSM) Report:
div.p: A tensile bench was installed in the beamline as show in the image below. The sample was heated locally with a "hot shoe" set up having a hole for allowing the incomding beam to illuminate the sample (see figure below on the right).

analytic.title: In Situ WAXD and SAXS during Tensile Deformation Of Moulded and Sintered Polyamide 12

biblStruct.note: is provided in the figure below

During the deformation process, the sample is heated locally and simultanesously drawn. X-ray images (SAXS and WAXD) are acquired at regular intervals and therefore at increasing lambdas (=L/L0). An example of the data, containing a series of SAXS patterns at increasing deformation, is provided in the figure below.

monogr.title: From the initial isotropic lamellar structure, the sample achieves a highly oriented morphology with chains aligned along the draw direction. The insights gained in this work contributed to the publication of Multiscale Structure and Microscopic Deformation Mechanisms of Gel-Spun Ultrahigh-Molecular-Weight Polyethylene Fibers Macromolecules

biblStruct.note: the morphology of the material undergoes dramatic changes

Clearly, the morphology of the material undergoes dramatic changes. From the initial isotropic lamellar structure, the sample achieves a highly oriented morphology with chains aligned along the draw direction. The insights gained in this work contributed to the publication of Multiscale Structure and Microscopic Deformation Mechanisms of Gel-Spun Ultrahigh-Molecular-Weight Polyethylene Fibers Macromolecules 2019, 52, 14, 5207-5216.
